Summarization reduces the size of the routing table by consolidating multiple routes into a single summary route. When a specific route fails, EIGRP queries are contained within the area defined by the summary route, preventing the queries from spreading throughout the entire network. This containment of queries results in faster convergence because fewer routers need to process the queries and respond.

By building neighbor adjacencies in a squared fashion, you can reduce the diameter of the EIGRP network and limit the scope of query propagation. This means that when a link failure occurs, the query messages to recompute routes will have a smaller domain to traverse, leading to faster convergence. In a squared fashion, each router is directly connected to its neighbors, forming a square or grid-like topology.

This approach helps to minimize the query propagation delay and reduce the time required for reconvergence, allowing the network to converge quickly and maintain optimal routing paths.

questions.question_text:
Company XYZ, a global content provider, owns data centers on different continents. Their data center design involves a standard three-layer design with a Layer
3-only core. HSRP is used as the FHRP. They require VLAN extension across access switches in all data centers, and they plan to purchase a Layer 2 interconnection between two of their data centers in Europe. In the absence of other business or technical constraints, which termination point is optimal for the
Layer 2 interconnection?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The aggregation layer acts as the boundary between the access layer and the core layer. It is responsible for aggregating multiple access switches and providing connectivity to the core layer. By terminating the Layer 2 interconnection at the aggregation layer, you can effectively extend VLANs across the access switches in both data centers.

This approach allows for better control and management of Layer 2 connectivity while keeping the core layer as a Layer 3-only domain. It avoids extending Layer 2 beyond the necessary boundaries and helps isolate the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) domains, minimizing the impact of potential spanning tree issues.
